abstracts.cdata!:
The Andekaleka Hydroelectric Project in
            Madagascar was achieved. The Andekaleka Project was a major
            investment which made sense in the federal context of
            Madgscar's large hydro resources, high oil prices and
            projected levels of power demand. However, overly optimistic
            demand projections conveyed a sense of urgency to bring on a
            large, capital-intensive, indivisible investment. In
            hindsight, it seems that the Bank may not have fully
            appreciated the potential difficult that could rise from a
            combination of conditions prevailing t the project's
            inception (a) a financing set-up which made it difficult for
            Bank to supervise, directly, the consultants in charge of
            the project's execution, (b) parallel financing with a
            large number of co-lenders, limiting the availability of
            funds in the case of major changes in the cost estimates,
            (c) the newness of the Malagasy Electricity and Water
            Corporation (JIRAMA) as an implementing agency with the
            conspicuous absence of a financial manager, (d) the lack of
            agreement on a new tariff structure at the time of Credit
            approval and (e) a questionable data base for making
            projections of demand and financial targets. These
            conditions foreshadowed, to a certain degree, the resulting
            cost over runs, surplus hydro capacity, and difficulties for
            JIRAMA in meeting some of the financial covenants of the Credit.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project would meet the growth in
            electricity demand until 1992 in the Antananarivo area, and
            provide for the strengthening of JIRAMA. The major
            components of the project include: (a) a concrete diversion
            dam 10 m high and 125 m long, and an intake structure; (b) a
            tunnel 5.2 m in diameter and 4 km long; an underground power
            house for four 28-MW units, and tailrace and access tunnels;
            (c) two turbines and two 28-MW generators; (d) electrical
            and mechanical equipment; (e) a 138-kV, 150-km, transmission
            line to Antananarivo; (f) engineering services; (g)
            reservoir at Ankorahotra; and (h) technical assistance and
            training of JIRAMA staff.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Andekaleka Hydroelectric Project for
            Madagascar will meet the growth in electricity demand until
            1992 in the Antananarivo area, and provide for the
            strengthening of JIRAMA (Malagasy Electricity and Water
            Corporation). The major components of the project include:
            (a) a concrete diversion dam 10 m high and 125 m long, and
            an intake structure; (b) a tunnel 5.2 m in diameter and 4 km
            long; an underground power house for four 28-MW units, and
            tailrace and access tunnels; (c) two turbines and two 28-MW
            generators; (d) electrical and mechanical equipment; (e) a
            138-kV, 150-km, transmission line to Antananarivo; (f)
            engineering services; (g) reservoir at Ankorahotra; and (h)
            technical assistance and training of JIRAMA staff.
